AppBar Lives!

April 20th, 2005 · 2 Comments

Ralph emailed me the other day out of the blue with this message:

I’m a happy AppBar user for over eight years now and I really love your
great program. Thank you for it!! What’s really great, too, is the fact
that the old AppBar version 1.02 still works with the latest Windows
versions (I’m currently using Win XP SP2).

A little history: I wrote AppBar in the Summer of 1996 while working as an IT intern at PeopleSoft. It was written for two purposes: to speed up application launching before NT had a Start Menu and to teach me the Win32 API so I would better understand Windows programming. It was written on Windows NT 3.51 with Visual C++ and was one of the first open source freeware applications ever on Windows. At the time, the only source code you could find for GUI apps was in the MSDN samples. The fact that it still works almost 9 years later boggles my mind.

Thanks for writing Ralph and may you and AppBar have many happy years together in the future!

    recreate your AppBar in a lesser known, smaller and
    not so powerful programming language, and nothing
    ever satisfies my need for a simple, clean and
    UNBloated program launcher, except for your AppBar.

    So I keep coming back to it.

    Anyway… I just wanted to drop you a thanks
    again. I’ve emailed you before thanking you and
    asking if I could name my attempt AppBar also.

    Needless to say, I never released anything. I
    do have a working version of what I made, but
    it just doesn’t compare to yours.

    By the way, if you change your mind about working
    on AppBar again, I would be willing to pay a reg
    fee for it. Maybe like a pro version that is
    updated and maybe some new features, and still
    leave the 1.02 up as freeware.

    Hey, if you have paypal, I’d be more than happy
    to send you a donation now just to show my
    appreciation.

    Thanks and best regards,
    -Garrett

  • 2 Geena // Feb 27, 2009 at 12:22 pm

    Hey - me too! I always install AppBar on any new system I set up. It’s the easiest, most convenient, most unobtrusive and most memory-frugal launcher app I know of, and I must have tried them all over the past ten years. I kind of wish it had a sub-menu level, but otherwise it’s perfect.
